cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
Which group had a hit in the 1980s with 'Everybody Wants To Rule The World'?
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: 
To answer the question, I need to identify the group that released the song "Everybody Wants To Rule The World" in the 1980s. This song is well-known and is often associated with a specific band. I recall that the song was released in 1985 and became a significant hit during that decade. The band that performed this song is known for their distinctive sound and has had other popular songs as well. 

Answer: Tears for Fears

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
Which group had a hit in the 1980s with 'Everybody Wants To Rule The World'?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['"Everybody Wants to Rule the World" is a song recorded by English band Tears for Fears. It was written by Roland Orzabal, Ian Stanley and Chris Hughes with production handled by Hughes. The song was released in 1985 by Phonogram, Mercury and Vertigo Records as the third single from their second album, "Songs from the Big Chair" (1985). "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" is a new wave song. Its lyrics detail the desire humans have for control and power and centre on themes of corruption.\n', 'BULLET::::- "Everybody Wants to Rule the World", a 1985 song by English band Tears for Fears\n', '"Everybody Wants to Rule the World" was co-written by Roland Orzabal, Ian Stanley and Chris Hughes, with production from the Dave Bascombe with engineering. It was released in 1985 through Phonogram, Mercury and Vertigo Records as the third single from the band\'s second album, "Songs from the Big Chair". The song was released for sale (as a 7-inch, 10-inch and 12-inch vinyl set) which included its B-side, interviews from the band and different versions of the song. To accommodate the vinyl release, a CD video set was also distributed and included the song\'s music video along audios of bonus tracks.\n', 'Music critics praised "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" in their retrospective reviews, with some including the song in their respective decade lists. It is regarded as the group\'s signature song, along with "Shout" (1984). Commercially, the song garnered success on charts internationally, peaking at number two in Ireland and the United Kingdom and at number one in Canada, New Zealand and on the "Billboard" Hot 100. "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" was certified gold by both Music Canada (MC) and the British Phonographic Industry (BPI).\n', 'In the United Kingdom, "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" debuted at number 16 on the UK Singles Chart, in the issue dated 24 March 1985. On the week of 14 April 1985, the song peaked at number two, behind the charity single "We Are the World" (1985) recorded by the supergroup United Support of Artists (USA) for Africa. "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" received a gold certification by the British Phonographic Industry (BPI) on 13 April 2018 for 500,000 sales. The song peaked at number three in Belgium and at number two in both the Netherlands and Ireland. In Canada, the song reached the number one spot, earning a gold certification from Music Canada (MC) for 40,000 sales shipments on 1 May 1985. In Australia, the song reached the number two position. On the report dated 19 May 1985, the song debuted at number four on the New Zealand Top 40 Singles chart; it would later peak at number one. It was certified Gold by the Recorded Music NZ (RMNZ) for sales of 10,000.\n', '"Everybody Wants to Rule the World" was voted the 25th best single in "The Village Voice"s Pazz & Jop critics\' poll for 1985 with 17 points, sharing the spot with Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers\' "Don\'t Come Around Here No More" (1985) and Sade\'s "Smooth Operator" (1984). "Pitchfork" placed the song at number 82 on their list for the best songs of the 80s expressing that "underneath the synth-pop sheen, its vague message" and its lesson in how power-driven society could be, the song was able to reach "Reagan and Margaret-era youth fed up with political greed." Kevin Korber from "Spectrum Culture" ranked the song at 24 on his 80s decade list, calling the song a "testament to how much of a free-for-all the pop landscape was in the 1980s." Korber dismissed the song\'s vague lyrics but praised its complex melodic structure, saying it was "both the perfect representation of its time and a timeless composition." "Treble" included the song at number 49 on their decade list.\n', 'In the United States, "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" debuted at number 70 on the "Billboard" Hot 100 in the issue dated 16 March 1985. On the week of 27 April 1985, the song rose to number 18. On the week of 8 June 1985, the song moved 2-1, replacing Wham!\'s "Everything She Wants" (1984) as the number one on the chart; it would spent a total of two weeks in this position. The song was a commercial success in other American markets, peaking at number two on the Adult Contemporary and Top Rock Tracks and charting at number one on the Hot Dance Club Play, Hot Dance Music/Maxi-Singles Sales and "Cash Box" charts.\n', 'BULLET::::- "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" – released on "Punk Goes 80s" (2005)\n', '"Everybody Wants to Rule the World" was written by Roland Orzabal, Ian Stanley and Chris Hughes with production handled by the latter. It was revealed that the song was a "last-minute" addition during recording sessions of "Songs from the Big Chair" (1985). The decision to include the song in the album came after Orzabal played two chords on his acoustic guitar for Hughes. It was recorded in two weeks and later added as the final track on the album. According to Orzabal, he initially regarded the song as a lightweight that would not fit with the rest of the album.\n', 'BULLET::::1. "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" (Chris Hughes, Roland Orzabal, Ian Stanley) – 5:34\n']

To answer the question regarding which group had a hit in the 1980s with "Everybody Wants To Rule The World," we can extract and analyze several key pieces of information from the provided passages. 

### Extracted Content:
1. **Artist Information**: The song "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" was recorded by the English band **Tears for Fears**.
2. **Release Details**: The song was released in **1985** as the third single from their second album, **"Songs from the Big Chair."**
3. **Songwriters and Production**: It was co-written by **Roland Orzabal**, **Ian Stanley**, and **Chris Hughes**, with production handled by Chris Hughes.
4. **Musical Genre**: The song is categorized as a **new wave** song.
5. **Themes**: The lyrics explore themes of **control, power, and corruption**.
6. **Commercial Success**: The song achieved significant commercial success, peaking at number one on the **Billboard Hot 100** and reaching high positions in various international charts, including number two in the UK and Ireland, and number one in Canada and New Zealand.
7. **Critical Reception**: It is regarded as the band's signature song and has been included in various decade-end lists by music critics, indicating its lasting impact and recognition.

### Analysis of the Role of Extracted Content:
- **Identification of the Artist**: Knowing that Tears for Fears is the band behind the song is crucial for answering the question directly. This establishes the primary subject of inquiry.
  
- **Context of Release**: The year of release (1985) situates the song within the 1980s, confirming its relevance to the question. The mention of the album "Songs from the Big Chair" provides additional context about the band's work during that period.

- **Songwriting and Production**: Understanding who wrote and produced the song adds depth to the knowledge of the band's creative process and highlights the collaborative nature of music production in that era.

- **Musical Genre and Themes**: Recognizing the song as part of the new wave genre and its thematic content helps contextualize its cultural significance and the type of music that was popular during the 1980s.

- **Commercial Success**: The song's chart performance and certifications (like gold status) illustrate its popularity and impact, reinforcing its status as a significant hit of the decade.

- **Critical Reception**: The inclusion of the song in various critics' lists indicates its artistic merit and enduring legacy, which is important for understanding its place in music history.

### Conclusion:
The extracted content provides a comprehensive background that enhances the understanding of the question. It not only identifies the group responsible for the hit but also situates the song within its historical, cultural, and musical context, allowing for a richer appreciation of its significance in the 1980s music landscape.

The song "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" is a significant cultural artifact from the 1980s, recorded by the English band Tears for Fears. Here’s a consolidated summary of the key points from the retrieved passages, which can deepen understanding of the song and its context:

1. **Artist and Release Information**:
   - The song was recorded by **Tears for Fears**, an English band, and was released in **1985** as the third single from their second album, **"Songs from the Big Chair."** 
   - It was co-written by **Roland Orzabal**, **Ian Stanley**, and **Chris Hughes**, with Hughes also handling production.

2. **Musical and Lyrical Themes**:
   - Musically, "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" is classified as a **new wave** song, characterized by its synth-pop elements.
   - The lyrics explore themes of **control, power, and corruption**, reflecting a broader commentary on human desires and societal issues, which resonated with the political climate of the 1980s.

3. **Commercial Success**:
   - The song achieved significant commercial success, peaking at **number one** on the **Billboard Hot 100** in the United States and reaching the top of charts in several other countries, including Canada and New Zealand.
   - It received **gold certifications** from both the British Phonographic Industry (BPI) and Music Canada, indicating high sales figures.

4. **Critical Reception**:
   - Critics have praised the song over the years, often including it in lists of the best songs of the decade. It is regarded as one of Tears for Fears' signature songs, alongside "Shout."
   - The song's ability to capture the sentiments of the era, particularly among youth disillusioned with political greed, has been noted in various retrospective reviews.

5. **Cultural Impact**:
   - The song's message and catchy melody contributed to its lasting popularity, making it a staple of 1980s music and a frequent subject of analysis regarding its lyrical content and societal implications.
   - It has been included in various compilations and covered by other artists, further cementing its place in pop culture.

By synthesizing this information, one can appreciate not only the song's commercial success but also its deeper cultural significance. Understanding the context in which "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" was created enhances comprehension of its themes and the reasons for its enduring popularity. This knowledge can inform discussions about the impact of music on societal attitudes and the role of artists in reflecting and shaping cultural narratives.

', 'BULLET::::- "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" – released on "Punk Goes 80s" (2005)
', '"Everybody Wants to Rule the World" was written by Roland Orzabal, Ian Stanley and Chris Hughes with production handled by the latter. It was revealed that the song was a "last-minute" addition during recording sessions of "Songs from the Big Chair" (1985). The decision to include the song in the album came after Orzabal played two chords on his acoustic guitar for Hughes. It was recorded in two weeks and later added as the final track on the album. According to Orzabal, he initially regarded the song as a lightweight that would not fit with the rest of the album.
', 'BULLET::::1. "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" (Chris Hughes, Roland Orzabal, Ian Stanley) – 5:34
']

cognition.content:
Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.
You are a scientist researching fact-checking and addressing model illusions in artificial intelligence. 
To answer the following question:
Which group had a hit in the 1980s with 'Everybody Wants To Rule The World'?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['"Everybody Wants to Rule the World" is a song recorded by English band Tears for Fears. It was written by Roland Orzabal, Ian Stanley and Chris Hughes with production handled by Hughes. The song was released in 1985 by Phonogram, Mercury and Vertigo Records as the third single from their second album, "Songs from the Big Chair" (1985). "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" is a new wave song. Its lyrics detail the desire humans have for control and power and centre on themes of corruption.\n', 'BULLET::::- "Everybody Wants to Rule the World", a 1985 song by English band Tears for Fears\n', '"Everybody Wants to Rule the World" was co-written by Roland Orzabal, Ian Stanley and Chris Hughes, with production from the Dave Bascombe with engineering. It was released in 1985 through Phonogram, Mercury and Vertigo Records as the third single from the band\'s second album, "Songs from the Big Chair". The song was released for sale (as a 7-inch, 10-inch and 12-inch vinyl set) which included its B-side, interviews from the band and different versions of the song. To accommodate the vinyl release, a CD video set was also distributed and included the song\'s music video along audios of bonus tracks.\n', 'Music critics praised "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" in their retrospective reviews, with some including the song in their respective decade lists. It is regarded as the group\'s signature song, along with "Shout" (1984). Commercially, the song garnered success on charts internationally, peaking at number two in Ireland and the United Kingdom and at number one in Canada, New Zealand and on the "Billboard" Hot 100. "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" was certified gold by both Music Canada (MC) and the British Phonographic Industry (BPI).\n', 'In the United Kingdom, "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" debuted at number 16 on the UK Singles Chart, in the issue dated 24 March 1985. On the week of 14 April 1985, the song peaked at number two, behind the charity single "We Are the World" (1985) recorded by the supergroup United Support of Artists (USA) for Africa. "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" received a gold certification by the British Phonographic Industry (BPI) on 13 April 2018 for 500,000 sales. The song peaked at number three in Belgium and at number two in both the Netherlands and Ireland. In Canada, the song reached the number one spot, earning a gold certification from Music Canada (MC) for 40,000 sales shipments on 1 May 1985. In Australia, the song reached the number two position. On the report dated 19 May 1985, the song debuted at number four on the New Zealand Top 40 Singles chart; it would later peak at number one. It was certified Gold by the Recorded Music NZ (RMNZ) for sales of 10,000.\n', '"Everybody Wants to Rule the World" was voted the 25th best single in "The Village Voice"s Pazz & Jop critics\' poll for 1985 with 17 points, sharing the spot with Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers\' "Don\'t Come Around Here No More" (1985) and Sade\'s "Smooth Operator" (1984). "Pitchfork" placed the song at number 82 on their list for the best songs of the 80s expressing that "underneath the synth-pop sheen, its vague message" and its lesson in how power-driven society could be, the song was able to reach "Reagan and Margaret-era youth fed up with political greed." Kevin Korber from "Spectrum Culture" ranked the song at 24 on his 80s decade list, calling the song a "testament to how much of a free-for-all the pop landscape was in the 1980s." Korber dismissed the song\'s vague lyrics but praised its complex melodic structure, saying it was "both the perfect representation of its time and a timeless composition." "Treble" included the song at number 49 on their decade list.\n', 'In the United States, "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" debuted at number 70 on the "Billboard" Hot 100 in the issue dated 16 March 1985. On the week of 27 April 1985, the song rose to number 18. On the week of 8 June 1985, the song moved 2-1, replacing Wham!\'s "Everything She Wants" (1984) as the number one on the chart; it would spent a total of two weeks in this position. The song was a commercial success in other American markets, peaking at number two on the Adult Contemporary and Top Rock Tracks and charting at number one on the Hot Dance Club Play, Hot Dance Music/Maxi-Singles Sales and "Cash Box" charts.\n', 'BULLET::::- "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" – released on "Punk Goes 80s" (2005)\n', '"Everybody Wants to Rule the World" was written by Roland Orzabal, Ian Stanley and Chris Hughes with production handled by the latter. It was revealed that the song was a "last-minute" addition during recording sessions of "Songs from the Big Chair" (1985). The decision to include the song in the album came after Orzabal played two chords on his acoustic guitar for Hughes. It was recorded in two weeks and later added as the final track on the album. According to Orzabal, he initially regarded the song as a lightweight that would not fit with the rest of the album.\n', 'BULLET::::1. "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" (Chris Hughes, Roland Orzabal, Ian Stanley) – 5:34\n']

question_info.question: Which group had a hit in the 1980s with 'Everybody Wants To Rule The World'?
passages:
"Everybody Wants to Rule the World" is a song recorded by English band Tears for Fears. It was written by Roland Orzabal, Ian Stanley and Chris Hughes with production handled by Hughes. The song was released in 1985 by Phonogram, Mercury and Vertigo Records as the third single from their second album, "Songs from the Big Chair" (1985). "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" is a new wave song. Its lyrics detail the desire humans have for control and power and centre on themes of corruption.
BULLET::::- "Everybody Wants to Rule the World", a 1985 song by English band Tears for Fears
"Everybody Wants to Rule the World" was co-written by Roland Orzabal, Ian Stanley and Chris Hughes, with production from the Dave Bascombe with engineering. It was released in 1985 through Phonogram, Mercury and Vertigo Records as the third single from the band's second album, "Songs from the Big Chair". The song was released for sale (as a 7-inch, 10-inch and 12-inch vinyl set) which included its B-side, interviews from the band and different versions of the song. To accommodate the vinyl release, a CD video set was also distributed and included the song's music video along audios of bonus tracks.
Music critics praised "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" in their retrospective reviews, with some including the song in their respective decade lists. It is regarded as the group's signature song, along with "Shout" (1984). Commercially, the song garnered success on charts internationally, peaking at number two in Ireland and the United Kingdom and at number one in Canada, New Zealand and on the "Billboard" Hot 100. "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" was certified gold by both Music Canada (MC) and the British Phonographic Industry (BPI).
In the United Kingdom, "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" debuted at number 16 on the UK Singles Chart, in the issue dated 24 March 1985. On the week of 14 April 1985, the song peaked at number two, behind the charity single "We Are the World" (1985) recorded by the supergroup United Support of Artists (USA) for Africa. "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" received a gold certification by the British Phonographic Industry (BPI) on 13 April 2018 for 500,000 sales. The song peaked at number three in Belgium and at number two in both the Netherlands and Ireland. In Canada, the song reached the number one spot, earning a gold certification from Music Canada (MC) for 40,000 sales shipments on 1 May 1985. In Australia, the song reached the number two position. On the report dated 19 May 1985, the song debuted at number four on the New Zealand Top 40 Singles chart; it would later peak at number one. It was certified Gold by the Recorded Music NZ (RMNZ) for sales of 10,000.
"Everybody Wants to Rule the World" was voted the 25th best single in "The Village Voice"s Pazz & Jop critics' poll for 1985 with 17 points, sharing the spot with Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers' "Don't Come Around Here No More" (1985) and Sade's "Smooth Operator" (1984). "Pitchfork" placed the song at number 82 on their list for the best songs of the 80s expressing that "underneath the synth-pop sheen, its vague message" and its lesson in how power-driven society could be, the song was able to reach "Reagan and Margaret-era youth fed up with political greed." Kevin Korber from "Spectrum Culture" ranked the song at 24 on his 80s decade list, calling the song a "testament to how much of a free-for-all the pop landscape was in the 1980s." Korber dismissed the song's vague lyrics but praised its complex melodic structure, saying it was "both the perfect representation of its time and a timeless composition." "Treble" included the song at number 49 on their decade list.
In the United States, "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" debuted at number 70 on the "Billboard" Hot 100 in the issue dated 16 March 1985. On the week of 27 April 1985, the song rose to number 18. On the week of 8 June 1985, the song moved 2-1, replacing Wham!'s "Everything She Wants" (1984) as the number one on the chart; it would spent a total of two weeks in this position. The song was a commercial success in other American markets, peaking at number two on the Adult Contemporary and Top Rock Tracks and charting at number one on the Hot Dance Club Play, Hot Dance Music/Maxi-Singles Sales and "Cash Box" charts.
BULLET::::- "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" – released on "Punk Goes 80s" (2005)
"Everybody Wants to Rule the World" was written by Roland Orzabal, Ian Stanley and Chris Hughes with production handled by the latter. It was revealed that the song was a "last-minute" addition during recording sessions of "Songs from the Big Chair" (1985). The decision to include the song in the album came after Orzabal played two chords on his acoustic guitar for Hughes. It was recorded in two weeks and later added as the final track on the album. According to Orzabal, he initially regarded the song as a lightweight that would not fit with the rest of the album.
BULLET::::1. "Everybody Wants to Rule the World" (Chris Hughes, Roland Orzabal, Ian Stanley) – 5:34
